content:
I have no idea, as you have not actually advised what the error message your receive is, or what steps you take before receiving it. As an initial install has to create a firstr profile that this error message is going to be very important.

Did you download from thunderbird.net or the windows store?


There is lots that can go wrong. Usually post an update it will be the antivirus software firewall or VPN that stops Thunderbird working. But like you have most folk assume the issue is in Thunderbird and start messing with settings and deleting things. The result is usually not good as a perfectly working profile is sliced and diced and the underlying problem is not addressed so the subsequent reinstall and adding of mail accounts and contacts fails for the same reason mail retrieval failed in the first place. Personally I use Defender because it does not meddle in email at all. I gave up on Norton and McAfee more than a decade ago alarmist products that hamper more than help usually. With the demise of Kaspersky in the US and some other jurisdictions. I have found Defender does it's stated job quietly in the background without fuss.

Some antivirus products also just can not accept you don't want to use their VPN, so mail fails when they automatically re enable it and the provider refuses to connect you to their mail server because you are not connecting from a known address. In the case of some ISP's the IP address used to connect must be one they issued on connection to the internet.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Hello Matt. I have the same issue and it does seem to be the header information that is being printed. Is it possible to switch this off and see only the necessary e-mail info such as sender, recipients, time sent, subject, body, and signature? See attached example. Your help would be appreciated.
creator: info3029

content:
The following methods might be helpful:

Method 1: (In menu bar) "View" > "Headers" > Tick "Normal".

If you do not see menu bar, the following steps might be helpful: Right click on the bar where hamburger button (three horizontal bar icon on the top right corner) locates > Tick "Menu Bar".

Method 2: (On Message Pane) "More" > "Customize" > Untick "Show all headers" > "Done".
creator: Yu5tiqX9og

content: Thanks for that. Problem solved.
creator: graeme_edwards

content:
a Thunderbird message pop up on screen every few seconds stating that it cannot connect to the dead email service.

Was your account IMAP with the now discontinued email service? If so then most likely you did not have offline copies of your messages, so every time you try to access messages from that account you get that error. What you should have done was to download all your messages from the server to your Local Folders account. But it's too late now for that. Do you have a backup of your message archive? If so, you may want to restore that to your Local Folders account, and delete the now dysfunctional account for the discontinued email service.
creator: christ1

content:
Update: The solution to this issue was found in Thunderbird's Server Settings for each email address, and the problem was solved by changing the settings.

How to do this? 1. Open Thunderbird 2. In the left column, right click an email account and select Settings 3. An Acccount Settings window opens: untick the boxes with ticks. 4. It may also be necessaary to delete or modify the Outgoing Server (MTP) details.

Note: the uploaded image below is not necessary, but is a warning message as described in the previous post.

content: The profile is at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles\<profilename>, so reinstalls do not address the issue. A possibility that is somewhat common is that a vpn or antivirus may be preventing thunderbird from updating the prefs.js file in the profile that stores all of that information. Sometimes, that is because it is read-only, and sometimes extra copies are created, such as prefs-1.js. This may not be the specific problem, but it sounds like it. When thunderbird works fine until shutdown and restart, something is interrupting the save.

content: It sounds frustrating! I’ve had similar issues before, and what worked for me was deleting the password manager data manually and letting Thunderbird re-save them. Also, running Thunderbird in safe mode can help eliminate any conflicting add-ons. If nothing works, it might be worth trying to create a new profile to start fresh. Sometimes, even with reinstalling, remnants from the old setup can cause these issues to persist. Hope it gets fixed soon!
creator: wirkutskijkarl

content: If the issue is a vpn or antivirus, the problem may remain. There is nothing wrong with a profile; somehow it isn't updating. Good luck on that. Yes, you can change profile location easily if you're comfortable with windows file explorer - exit thunderbird first - VERY important - copy the exact profile to wherever and rename it as desired if unsure of profile specifically, just type help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profile folder', click 'open folder', exit thunderbird, and you're there. back up one folder so you will be copying the entire profile - after COPYing it to new location, open the profiles.ini (text file) in the ...appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder and overtype the location pointer to point to the new profile. save and restart thunderbird. when comfortable, then delete the ..appdata\roamng\thunderbird\profiles folder.
creator: davidsk

content: - help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird - go to either imapmail\<accountname> or mail]<POPaccountname> folder - your desired message folders should appear. ignore the msf files - COPY the desired folders to Mail\Local Folders folder - restart thunderbird and verify that you can read the copied folders - then remove the old account

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

This crash is caused by bitdefender https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1940810

Download and install the latest version from https://www.thunderbird.net/download/

Let us know whether the crashing stops. If the crashing does not stop, you will need to update bitdefender or make some other adjustment.

content:
The biggest risk is probably that others can access unencrypted messages in transit and at rest on a server.

If you are worried, you will want to use Proton for all mail. They have a bridge application that may work with Thunderbird.

You could also encrypt messages within Thunderbird. Of course, you will need your recipients’ public keys and your correspondents will need your public key.

The Thunderbird email client does not use the Mozilla Accounts. What Mozilla Accounts are used for (used to be called Firefox Account). https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/access-mozilla-services-firefox-account

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/mozilla-account-deletion-inactivity https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/sumo-profile-inactive-deleted

This support.mozilla.org site uses Mozilla Account to login. If the email was about the Mozilla Account you are using to post this thread then you should be fine now as you have logged in to the Mozilla Account before the date.

On January 28, 2020, the Mozilla Foundation announced that the project (Thunderbird) would henceforth be operating from a new wholly owned subsidiary, MZLA Technologies Corporation, in order to explore offering products and services that were not previously possible and to collect revenue through partnerships and non-charitable donations.

content:
Add-ons, whether random or not, serve important user needs, which is to fill gaps in functionality. Add-on authors, at least in Thunderbird are a trustworthy breed of developers, and add-ons are reviewed.

What you saw was just a mock up. Avatars will eventually become core code, but I don't believe it is on this year's road map.
